title: R40521
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) is the federal statute for educating children with disabilities, providing funding and setting principles for special education services. It requires states to offer a free appropriate public education (FAPE) to all eligible children, assess their needs, and create individual education programs (IEPs) for those receiving services. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) mandates evaluating all children with disabilities for special education eligibility, creating individual education programs (IEPs) for services, involving parents in planning, promoting inclusion, and providing procedural safeguards. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) provides rights to parents, including due process hearings and appeals to federal court. It was enacted in 1975 to ensure education for children with disabilities. IDEA has undergone multiple reauthorizations, with the most recent in 2004. Congress is now considering potential issues for the next reauthorization. The act defines a child with a disability differently from the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) defines a child with a disability categorically, requiring special education and related services. Disabilities include mental retardation, hearing impairments, speech or language impairments, visual impairments, emotional disturbance, orthopedic impairments, autism, traumatic brain injury, other health impairments, or specific learning disabilities.
